text:
Trying to implement the _fetch_files, it was not clear that the tuple (file_name,url,dict) required an actual file name to check, after finishing a successful download, if the file_name given is not exactly something inside the downloaded file the whole download gets cancelled. 

Could there be an option to not require the file check? or to keep the download no matter what?
title: Misleading documentation of _fetch_files in utils.py

text: text
title: title

text:
This PR adds an utility function check_embedded_nifti_masker, that retrieves a MultiNiftiMasker / NiftiMasker from the parameters of a given estimator instance.

This would be useful in decomposition module, spacenet module, spectral clustering module, and would help sorting issue #688 

Ping @dohmatob @ahoyosid @AlexandreAbraham @GaelVaroquaux
title: [MRG] Added check_embedded_nifti_masker

text:
This PR adds an utility function check_embedded_nifti_masker, that retrieves a MultiNiftiMasker / NiftiMasker from the parameters of a given estimator instance.

This would be useful in decomposition module, spacenet module, spectral clustering module, and would help sorting issue #688 

Ping @dohmatob @ahoyosid @AlexandreAbraham @GaelVaroquaux
title: [MRG] Added check_embedded_nifti_masker

text:
This is true. However, doing the opposite is difficult to do in a clean way as we would need to check if user has explicitly provided non default argument.

The bottom line is that I don't think that it makes any sense to allow the user to create a masker and override its parameters in an estimator class.

This warning is especially useful to warn the user that he provided a masker that diverges from default masker embedded within an estimator class (providing 'detrend' = False in MultiPCA for instance)

text:
You can get away from using backslashes in a lot of cases in Python:

``` python
conflict_string += ("Parameter {0:s} :\n"
                    "    Masker parameter {1:s}"
                    "...").format(...)
```

text:
for 4d images. The dtype after resampling was always 'float64' for 4d images
- Share same code for 3d and 4d images
- add test for dtype equality before and after resampling

An example that highlights the issue:

``` python
import numpy as np

import nibabel as nib

from nilearn import image

img_4d = nib.Nifti1Image(np.ones((10, 10, 10, 5), dtype='int64'), np.eye(4))
resampled_img = image.resample_img(img_4d, 2. * np.eye(4))
print('img_4d dtype:       ', img_4d.get_data().dtype)
print('resampled_img dtype:', resampled_img.get_data().dtype)
```

and its output:

```
img_4d dtype:        int64
resampled_img dtype: float64
```
title: [MRG] Fix output data dtype after resampling for 4d images
[MRG] Fix output data dtype after resampling for 4d images

text:
for 4d images. The dtype after resampling was always 'float64' for 4d images

- add test for dtype equality before and after resampling

An example that highlights the issue:

``` python
import numpy as np

import nibabel as nib

from nilearn import image

img_4d = nib.Nifti1Image(np.ones((10, 10, 10, 5), dtype='int64'), np.eye(4))
resampled_img = image.resample_img(img_4d, 2. * np.eye(4))
print('img_4d dtype:       ', img_4d.get_data().dtype)
print('resampled_img dtype:', resampled_img.get_data().dtype)
```

and its output:

```
img_4d dtype:        int64
resampled_img dtype: float64
```

text:
I agree that the inconsistency in the behavior of the function is a bug. However, casting to float, in my opinion, is the way to go if resample_img is called with `interpolation="continuous"`. Because continuous interpolation implies that the values are continuous. For the record, we already do that in `smooth_img`.

So I am :-1: for the behavior proposed here.

> I agree that the inconsistency in the behavior of the function is a bug. However, casting to float, in my opinion, is the way to go if resample_img is called with interpolation="continuous".

Sounds good.
I resuscitated this one. Comments welcome!
nice :)

text:
Well, blaming is the word here. It is far less readable than `[:, :, :]` and highly inefficient. There is an iterator to iterate on non-first dimensions, it is `np.nested_iters`. However this is not the fastest solution, transposing the axes is even faster. It has to be noted that, for that particular purpose, a `nditer` may be the faster solution because it would iter on both arrays at the same time.

Here is a small bench to convince you.

``` python
import numpy as np
import time


a = np.random.random((20, 30, 40, 5, 6))

t0 = time.time()
for i in range(100):
    all_img = (slice(None), ) * 3
    other_shape = a.shape[3:]
    for ind in np.ndindex(*other_shape):
        a[all_img + ind].shape
print time.time() - t0

t0 = time.time()
for i in range(100):
    it0, it1 = np.nested_iters(a, [range(3, a.ndim), [0, 1, 2]], flags=['multi_index'])
    for x in it0:
        it1.itviews[0].shape
print time.time() - t0

t0 = time.time()
for i in range(100):
    other_shape = a.shape[3:]
    b = np.transpose(a, range(3, a.ndim) + [0, 1, 2])
    b = np.reshape(b, (-1,) + a.shape[:3])
    for x in b:
        x
print time.time() - t0
```

Output:

```
0.00588703155518
0.00144195556641
0.000957012176514
```

title: Have the niimgs checking function optionally convert globbing
Have the niimgs checking function optionally convert globbing

text:
> To sum up the work to be done:
> - Have check_niimg optionally use glob (and sort if using glob) (with the default being true)
> - Have a constant at the level of nilearn.init to control this behavior
> - Have a very clear error message if a glob returns an empty list, that explains what is going on, and > assumes that the user might have made a glob by mistake (thus points out the above constant).

@GaelVaroquaux, I pushed 419019a that should address this feature. A test is missing though.

I think it's YAGNI, and we'll bring us more trouble than the anticipated good it might do for users. Let them expand their paths themselves. Also, `nilearn.plotting` is not supposed to be a unix shell environment ;)

To sum up the work to be done:
- Have check_niimg optionally use glob (and sort if using glob) (with the default being true)
- Have a constant at the level of `nilearn.__init__` to control this behavior
- Have a very clear error message if a glob returns an empty list, that explains what is going on, and assumes that the user might have made a glob by mistake (thus points out the above constant).
Maybe this behavior should be restricted to `check_niimg_4d`?

> Maybe this behavior should be restricted to check_niimg_4d?

Well, if we want to expand '~' we can do it in check_niimg. But for the
rest, I agree.
I agree with Gael that glob-integration could increase comfort of nilearn users. After all, we do glob.glob before loading anyways.
@aabadie  It would be nice if you do PR tagged as **[WIP]** and ping somebody if you need help.

> @aabadie It would be nice if you do PR tagged as [WIP] and ping somebody if you need help.

:+1: in general commenting on commits is not a really good idea, because comments tend to be completely lost if there is a rebase. It is a lot better to start a PR so that the discussion happens all in one place.

text
title: title

text:
In datasets, some atlases uses "maps" for the brain maps and "labels" for the name of the regions. For some atlases, we want to use "labels" for the brain components since the atlas is actually contained in a single label map but we can't because this would clash with other datasets.

I think we should follow the same convention for all atlases.

Also, I think that it would be good to always return a dictionary when we associate label values to names, even if they are integer. It is easier to use and more consistent.
title: Naming conflicts in datasets

text: text
title: title

text:
Address #720 step 1.2, 1.3 and 3.1.

The goal here is to establish a common basis for NiftiMasker, NiftiLabelsMasker and NiftiMapsMasker. There are a lot of advantages:
- NiftiMasker features come for free in Nifti*Maskers (sessions and sample masks)
- If we design it well, MultiNifti_Masker flavors will come for free for all Nifti_Maskers.
- Code is slightly more complicated (very slightly actually) but much smaller, making maintenance and bug tracking easier.

Steps done:
- [x] Make `filter_and_mask` rely on `filter_and_extract`
- [x] Make NiftiSpheresMasker rely on `filter_and_extract`
- [x] Make `BaseMasker` more generic. NiftiLabelsMasker and NiftiMapsMasker should inherit from it.
- [x] Make `MultiNiftiMasker` independant by inheriting `NiftiMasker`
title: [MRG] Use filter_and_extract as a basis signal extractor.
[MRG] Use filter_and_extract as a basis signal extractor.

text: added test
@AlexandreAbraham I fixed all the comments, and about the naming I finally changed anat for maps, which i think follow the convention behind the other atlases.

I realized that when it comes to what to return there is no standard across atlases, some return directly a nibable.Niftiimage while others return the file name, with respect to labels, some just return a list while I am returning a dictionary... Should this be reported as an issue?

> about the naming I finally changed anat for maps

This is misleading: your atlas cannot be trated by NiftiMapsMasker, it should be fed to NiftiLabelsMasker.

> some return directly a nibable.Niftiimage while others return the file name

When a Nifti1Image is returned, it is probably that some processing of the atlas was required. However, this doesn't matter as both are niimgs and can be processed by all nilearn functions.

> some just return a list while I am returning a dictionary

Well, a list can be seen as an "int to string" dictionary :P. I think that we should return dictionaries everywhere.

> Should this be reported as an issue?

Yes! We definitely need to harmonize the naming conventions and return types. However, I have no time to do it. Let's merge your PR and then solve the problem of the naming.
sorry i didnt understand the first comment, so what should I name it finally?
I don't know.
Regarding the naming: maybe label_masks or multi_mask ?
No other comment atm.
I changed the import and the name to multi_mask then
For me, it's even worse. People will try to stick it into the MultiNiftiMasker and wonder why it doesn't work.

@AlexandreAbraham  What if we use then something like "regions" and clarify in the documentation what people are supposed to do with the file?

All these problems with the naming, seem to me like something coming from problems in conventions in the rest of the framework, I think this should be opened as another issue and will likely lead to renaming the output of other atlases.

Yes, any naming like "atlas", "regions" or even "label_masks" is fine with me. I just don't want it to collide with other maskers name. We'll change it afterward when we'll agree on the right vocabulary.
Ok the name is 'regions' now
You have failing tests.

Seems like your failing test is related to the test, which is normal because ot tries to load an empty XML file. Take a look at the harvard oxford fetch function: we create a dummy XML file to avoid this kind of crash.
thank you for the tip @AlexandreAbraham, I think I fixed the test now following your advice.

It's getting there but you still have an error for Python 2.6 due to the fact that the `.iter` method is new in python 2.7. It looks like `.getiterator` although deprecated works for all the python versions we care about.

Yes we want a description if possible (not mandatory, you can skip it or make it short), and yes it should be exposed like the others :).

text: Issue #746 . Addressing inconsistencies giving a list of haxby datasets
Unfortunately you have a merge conflict with Alex's last commit, you need to rebase.
CircleCI blew up because of memory problem. This is weird since you rebased on master. @lesteve any thoughts on this one?

> CircleCI blew up because of memory problem. This is weird since you rebased on master. @lesteve any thoughts on this one?

That's weird indeed but I don't have any good suggestions as to why this is happening.
All green, :+1: to merge. @lesteve?
some .func haven't been replaced by .func[0] I think (for example in some print statements). Please double-check @KamalakerDadi.
Seems good to go now. @lesteve?
Seems good enough. I'll probably tweak one of the comments post-merge.
Cool, thx.
in a single list is not important enough to feature in the short explanation (first line of the docstring). Also it is slightly inaccurate.

list of string rather than string list.

About adding the hyphen in front of each line, have you checked how it renders in the html API reference documentation? Personally I wouldn't bother doing that in this PR. In case there is a neat improvement in term of html rendering, you would need to do that consistently for all the fetch_\* functions.

title: title

text: If we want to update the atlas to a new version, we will break all the existing scripts. We should change it to `fetch_atlas_aal_spm` or `fetch_atlas_aal`.
title: Function name fetch_atlas_aal_spm_12 is too specific
Function name fetch_atlas_aal_spm_12 is too specific

text: Ping @GaelVaroquaux

> Ping @GaelVaroquaux

.... @GaelVaroquaux is alive.

More seriously: fetch_atlas_aal is good. People don't even realize that
there is an SPM version of the AAL.

Originally I wrote fetch_atlas_aal. But I was told to make it more specific,  I guees if a new aal spm version is included, it would be as a separate atlas function. Actually the file structure is so different between versions that it might be better to just have them in separate fetch functions.

ahhh, i really understood you wanted me to change everything, actually i was passing a version parameter at the beginning, I would completely agree with that, If you want I can implement the change, its a second... 

Then the parameter would be used also to create the dataset folder with the version attached, nonetheless I think it would be misleading for a user to have the parameter in the function exposed when at the moment there is no download of other versions, so maybe we would also need to point out in the docs that other versions are not downloadable yet?

text:
Fix #762.

Amend test to highlight this bug and add one for plot_glass_brain.

Fix was to use dtype='auto' in check_niimg prior to vmin and vmax computation by _get_plot_stat_map_params.
